channel.title: NYT > World News

item.title: Israel Builds Bases in Central Gaza, a Sign It May Be There to Stay
item.description: In recent months, soldiers have demolished more than 600 buildings to create a buffer area and expanded a network of bases, a New York Times analysis of satellite imagery and video footage shows.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Aric Toler, Riley Mellen and Patrick Kingsley

item.title: Russia and Iran Pledge Support for Syria’s al-Assad Against Advancing Rebels
item.description: In just a few days, a patchwork of rebel forces has seized control of a broad stretch of land in the west and northwest of Syria. But it’s unclear just how much support Syria’s weakened allies can provide.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The aftermath of an airstrike that targeted Syria’s rebel-held northern city of Idlib on Monday.

item.title: What’s Behind the Protests in Georgia?
item.description: For days, pro-Western Georgians have clashed with police over the government’s plan to suspend plans for European Union membership.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins

item.title: Trump Says There Will Be ‘Hell to Pay’ Unless Hostages in Gaza Are Released
item.description: President-elect Donald J. Trump said in a social media post on Monday that the hostages must be released before his inauguration in January.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Images of hostage abducted to Gaza on Oct. 7, 2023, were displayed in Tel Aviv in February.

item.title: An Arctic Hamlet is Sinking Into the Thawing Permafrost
item.description: Canada is losing its permafrost to climate change. The Indigenous residents of Tuktoyaktuk know they’ll have to move but don’t agree on when.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Renaud Philippe
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times

item.title: Hezbollah and Israel Trade Fire, Further Testing Cease-Fire
item.description: Both sides have accused each other of violating the deal; Hezbollah fired into Israel for the first time since the truce took effect, and Israel responded with airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers patrolling near the Lebanese border in Avivim, Israel, on Monday.

item.title: Maternity Leave and Ongoing Consent: New Rights for Belgium’s Sex Workers
item.description: A groundbreaking law, which gives some sex workers greater labor protections and social benefits than similar legislation elsewhere in the world, is now in effect in the European country.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Dirk Waem/Belga, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A bedroom in a brothel in the red light district of Ghent, Belgium.

item.title: 5 Women Win Reparations From Belgium for Crimes Under Colonial Rule
item.description: In a landmark case, a court ruled that the women, now in their 70s and 80s, who were taken from their parents in Belgian Congo, were victims of a crime against humanity.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Elian Peltier
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ksenia Kuleshova for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Noelle Verbeken, Léa Tavares Mujinga and Simone Ngalula, three of the five women who sued the Belgian state for acts committed under colonial rule in Congo, in Brussels in 2021.

item.title: Tensions Rise Among Russia’s Elite as Economic Growth Slows
item.description: The slowdown is worrying for the Kremlin but not serious enough to significantly hobble its war effort.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: An ad at a bus stop showing a Russian soldier and the slogan “Be strong, faithful, courageous” in front of Moscow’s business district in November.

item.title: Who Is Massad Boulos, the Lebanese American Tycoon and Trump Adviser?
item.description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has selected Mr. Boulos, the businessman and father-in-law of Mr. Trump’s daughter, as a senior adviser on Arab and Middle Eastern affairs.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Nick Hagen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Massad Boulos, who was named as President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for senior adviser on Arab and Middle Eastern affairs, spoke to The New York Times in Detroit in October.

item.title: Clashes at Soccer Match Kill Dozens in Guinea
item.description: The military government said 56 people had been killed, but local media reported that the death toll could be as high as 100.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri, Saikou Jammeh and Abdourahmane Diallo

item.title: French Government Faces No-Confidence Vote Over Budget Bill
item.description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier pushed a budget bill through the lower house of Parliament without a vote. A no-confidence vote this week could topple him and his cabinet.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier, center, at the Parliament in Paris last month.

item.title: Biden Visits Angola to Promote Lobito Corridor and Counter China
item.description: When President Biden visits Angola on Monday, he will promote a rail project meant to show America’s commitment to the continent and to counter Chinese influence.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Joao Silva
item.media:description: A Chinese construction site in Luanda, the capital of Angola. China has been one of the biggest investors in the country.

item.title: What Can the World’s Top Court Do About Climate Change?
item.description: The International Court of Justice, the United Nations’ highest judicial body, is beginning landmark hearings on global warming. Here’s a guide.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mexico’s Valle de Bravo reservoir this year. The court has been asked what obligations governments have to protect the world’s climate system.

item.title: 3 Climbers From the U.S. and Canada Have Gone Missing on New Zealand’s Highest Mountain
item.description: Two Americans and a Canadian were climbing Mount Cook before failing to show up to a prearranged flight on Monday.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Mount Cook, also known as Aoraki, is the highest mountain in New Zealand.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Russian and Iranian support for Syria.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Russian airstrike hit Idlib in northern Syria yesterday.

item.title: France’s Prime Minister Could Be Forced to Resign This Week. Here’s What Could Happen Next.
item.description: A vote by Parliament could force the prime minister to resign, leaving his budget legislation in limbo.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier of France could face a no-confidence vote as soon as Wednesday, which, if it passes. would force him to resign.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: A Presidential Pardon
item.description: Plus, Free North Korea Radio.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: President Biden, left, and his son Hunter.

item.title: Who Are HTS, the Rebels Leading the Syria Offensive?
item.description: The group now advancing, Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, says it wants to replace the Assad government with one inspired by Islamic principles.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Alissa J. Rubin and Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fighter from Hayat Tahrir al-Sham at a frontline base in Maaret al-Naasan, Syria, in 2021. For several years, the group focused on securing and governing the area it held.

item.title: Germany Pledges Fast Military Aid to Ukraine in Effort to Reassure
item.description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz visited Kyiv on Monday. Amid fears that U.S. support could dry up, Ukrainian officials had criticized him for a recent phone call with President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, left, and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine visited a makeshift memorial in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Omer Neutra, Thought to Be Hostage in Gaza, Died on Oct. 7, IDF Says
item.description: Omer Neutra, who had Israeli and U.S. dual citizenship, was doing military service in Israel when Hamas invaded. His parents have been high-profile campaigners for the hostages.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Adam Gray for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members of Omer Neutra, a dual American-Israeli citizen who was in the Israeli military and was believed to be held alive in Gaza, at a vigil in New York City in September.

item.title: U.N. Suspends Aid Deliveries to Gaza via Kerem Shalom Crossing
item.description: The head of the U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees blamed Israel for failing to ensure safe conditions for delivering relief supplies from the Kerem Shalom crossing.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: Aid is distributed by UNRWA, the U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees, in Nuseirat, Gaza, in early November.

item.title: Biden Arrives in Angola on His Only Trip as President to Sub-Saharan Africa
item.description: The president arrived in Angola, where he will highlight American commitment to Africa in the economic competition against China.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden in Cape Verde on Monday. While Air Force One was refueled, he met in an airport lounge with the island nation’s prime minister.

item.title: Centrist Party Edges Out Far-Right Challengers in Romania
item.description: The center-left Social Democrats won the most votes in a parliamentary election but a strong nationalist showing could make it difficult to form a stable, Western-oriented government.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Voting in Mogosoaia, Romania, on Sunday. The parliamentary election came a week after a presidential vote in which a far-right candidate took a surprise first-round lead.

item.title: Inside a Secret Plan to Bring Uyghurs Trapped in China to the United States
item.description: On Thanksgiving eve, U.S. diplomats reunited family members who had not seen each other in years because of China’s harsh policies on the ethnic group.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Moriah Ratner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ayshem Mamut at her son’s home in Virginia on Sunday.

item.title: The Secret Pentagon War Game That ​Offers a Stark​ Warning for Our Times
item.description: The devastating outcome of the 1983 game reveals that nuclear escalation inevitably spirals out of control.
item.dc:creator: William Langewiesche
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: A North Korean Voice That Kim Jong-un Would Like to Silence
item.description: Kim Seongmin, who fled to South Korea in the 1990s, broadcasts to his homeland twice a day, delivering the kind of information Pyongyang is trying hard to suppress.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kim Seongmin, president of Free North Korea Radio, editing content for the station at his home in November. He has cancer and was recently told he has months to live.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: A presidential pardon for Hunter Biden.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Until Sunday night, President Biden had said that he would not pardon or commute the sentence of his son Hunter.

item.title: Syria’s Rebels Struck When Assad’s Allies Were Weakened and Distracted
item.description: Diminished support for the Syrian government from Iran, Hezbollah and Russia enabled opposition forces to take the initiative and seize new territory.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Opposition fighters loading ammunition onto a truck in northwestern Syria on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Rebels Advance in Syria
item.description: Plus, the vast network of undersea internet cables.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Anti-regime fighters near a road leading to Hama province.

item.title: Stowaway on Flight to Paris Disrupts a Return Flight to New York
item.description: The same passenger who stowed away on a Delta Air Lines flight to Paris caused a disturbance on a flight to New York on Saturday, an aviation official said.
item.dc:creator: Hank Sanders
item.media:description: The stowaway passenger who was caught on a Delta flight from New York to Paris days earlier was removed from a Paris to New York flight, also on Delta, after creating a disturbance on Saturday.

item.title: Ireland’s Main Parties Edge Out Sinn Féin, Early Election Results Show
item.description: At one level, the vote was an endorsement of continuity, but the stability in Ireland’s political center ground masked volatility on the fringes.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Dublin and the rest of Ireland, economic concerns and anxiety about immigration were top electoral issues.

item.title: Nations Fail to Reach an Agreement on Plastic Pollution
item.description: Talks on the world’s first treaty to tackle plastic pollution will continue in coming months, delegates said.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: The world produces nearly a half-billion tons of plastic each year, more than twice the amount produced two decades ago.

item.title: Former Defense Minister Accuses Israel of Committing War Crimes in Gaza
item.description: The comments by Moshe Yaalon were swiftly denied and condemned by allies of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, who said that they would hurt the country and help its enemies.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Liam Stack and Natan Odenheimer
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moshe Yaalon, left, who was the Israeli defense minister from 2013 to 2016, with Benny Gantz, who later held that role, in Tel Aviv in 2019.

item.title: Protesters in Tbilisi Clash With Georgian Police
item.description: The government’s decision to suspend its bid for European Union membership has driven thousands of protesters into the streets.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: The police used water cannons and tear gas on Sunday in Tbilisi, Georgia, during a rally outside the Parliament building prompted by the government’s move to suspend negotiations on joining the European Union.

item.title: Syria Rebels Take Aleppo Airport and Attack Hama, Officials and a Monitor Say
item.description: Forces opposed to President Bashar al-Assad have captured the Aleppo airport and are attacking the western city of Hama, according to local officials and a Britain-based war monitor.
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Haj Kadour and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Rebel fighters with an abandoned Syrian government tank in the east of Aleppo Province on Sunday.

item.title: A Power Vacuum in Gaza Could Empower Warlords and Gangs
item.description: Hamas’s weakened position could leave the territory without any governing institutions.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: A picture taken during a tour organized by the Israeli Army shows a Palestinian truck arriving Saturday to pick up aid destined for the Gaza Strip from a drop-off area near the Kerem Shalom crossing.

item.title: Angola, the U.S. and a Slavery Connection Few Talk About
item.description: When President Biden visits the country this week, he is expected to highlight a largely overlooked bond between Angola and the United States that was born out of the trans-Atlantic slave trade.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Joao Silva
item.media:description: A view of the Cuanza River in Massangano, Angola. Enslaved Angolans were transported by boat along the Cuanza River.

item.title: What a Marine Heat Wave Reveals About Our Warming Oceans
item.description: An extreme heat wave off California’s coast seemed like an anomaly 10 years ago. But as the ocean warms, the catastrophe may be a glimpse of the future.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa and Ian C. Bates
item.media:description: Rodeo Beach, Calif., one of the beaches that volunteers survey regularly for wildlife.

item.title: France’s Government Under Prime Minister Michel Barnier Faces Week of Reckoning
item.description: The end of Michel Barnier’s government looks inevitable, even imminent, and would add to the country’s political malaise. The only question seems to be: How long can he last?
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier of France after a cabinet meeting at the Élysée Palace in Paris last Wednesday.

item.title: Mexican Cartels Lure Chemistry Students to Make Fentanyl
item.description: Criminals turn college campuses into recruitment hubs, recruiting chemistry students in Mexico with big paydays.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Paulina Villegas
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 19-year-old sophomore chemistry major, who also works for the Sinaloa drug cartel, at a stash house.

item.title: 80 Years After Killings, Senegal Wants the Facts From France
item.description: The mass slaying of West African soldiers by colonial forces at the end of World War II in Senegal remains shrouded in secrecy. But Senegal’s new government won’t abide the mystery.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Saikou Jammeh
item.media:credit: Sylvain Cherkaoui for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Thiaroye military cemetery in Senegal has 35 graves representing West African soldiers that France said were killed by French Army soldiers in 1944. Historians said the actual death toll may be closer to 400.

item.title: Israel Accuses World Central Kitchen Worker of Role in Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: The Israeli military said it killed the worker in a strike in Gaza on Saturday. “To the best of our knowledge, no WCK team members are affiliated with Hamas,” a spokeswoman for the aid group said.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk
item.media:description: An Israeli airstrike damaged a vehicle carrying World Central Kitchen workers.

item.title: U.S. Condemns China’s Harsh Sentence for a Prominent Journalist
item.description: The sentencing of Dong Yuyu, a former Harvard Nieman fellow, signals that officials consider some exchanges between Chinese citizens and foreigners to be espionage.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:description: Dong Yuyu is the most prominent journalist imprisoned in mainland China.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Leads Pushback Against Global Plastic Treaty
item.description: Delegates from more than 170 countries are working to salvage a treaty that would tackle the growing problem of plastic pollution.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: An oil processing plant in Saudi Arabia, the world’s top oil exporter.

item.title: Russia Captures More Villages in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Russian forces are closing in on two strongholds. The fall of the cities could pave the way for a takeover of the southern part of the Donetsk region, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Damaged buildings in Kurakhove, Ukraine, last month, in an area targeted by Russian strikes.

item.title: Israel Strikes Sites in Lebanon Amid Fragile Cease-Fire
item.description: As the truce appeared to largely hold, a deal appeared far away in Gaza, where an Israeli strike killed dozens, according to a rescue group.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: A man looked over damage in Tyre, Lebanon, on Friday.

item.title: Giving Love
item.description: The act of giving a gift is a vehicle for showing people how you feel. Here are tips to find the perfect present.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Morrill

item.title: For Canada, Trade Tumult From Trump’s Return Has Begun
item.description: While the president-elect says he will impose a 25 percent tariff on everything Canada exports, Trudeau remains confident about forestalling that outcome.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau leaving his hotel on Friday to meet President-elect Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Rebels Seize Control Over Most of Syria’s Largest City in Aleppo
item.description: The rapid advance on Aleppo came just four days into a surprise opposition offensive that is the most intense escalation in years in the civil war.
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Haj Kadour and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Muhammad Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An opposition flag waves over a market square in central Aleppo, Syria, on Saturday.

item.title: Israel-Hezbollah Cease-Fire Rests on a Wobbly Linchpin: Lebanon’s Army
item.description: The Lebanese Army is tasked with ensuring that Hezbollah abides by the cease-fire. It has failed at that task before.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Members of the Lebanese Army at the site of an Israeli strike in central Beirut, earlier this month.

item.title: How Kennedy Has Worked Abroad to Weaken Global Public Health Policy
item.description: The health secretary pick and his organization have worked around the world to undermine longstanding policies on measles, AIDS and more.
item.dc:creator: Selam Gebrekidan, Justin Scheck, Sarah Hurtes and Pete McKenzie
item.media:credit: Uli Seit for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., an environmental lawyer, has spent years working abroad with organizations and associates that undermine longstanding global health policies, records show.

item.title: What Happens When Undersea Internet Cables Snap?
item.description: The internet is made up of hundreds of cables crossing the floors and the canyons of the earth’s oceans. So what happens when the cables snap? James Glanz, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, explains what could go wrong with subsea internet cables and how these cables get fixed.
item.dc:creator: James Glanz, Christina Shaman, James Surdam and Alexandra Ostasiewicz

item.title: Taiwan’s President Visits Pacific Islands to Counter China’s Influence
item.description: Lai Ching-te is looking to shore up support from three island nations that are among a dwindling number to keep diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Lai Ching-te, the Taiwanese president, at Taoyuan International Airport, Taiwan, on Saturday. He is scheduled to visit the Marshall Islands, Tuvalu and Palau.

item.title: Trudeau Meets With Trump at Mar- Amid Tariff Concerns
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada is the first foreign G7 leader to visit President-elect Donald J. Trump since the election. He is under pressure to persuade Mr. Trump to back down from his tariff threat.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justin Trudeau, prime minister of Canada, leaving his hotel in West Palm Beach, Fla., on Friday to meet with President-elect Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Nigeria Boat Capsizes, Killing at Least 27
item.description: Rescuers were searching for survivors after the vessel, taking passengers to a food market, capsized along the River Niger, officials said.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Olympia De Maismont/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The river Niger, pictured near Lokoja, Nigeria, last month.
